comment_text:
Some corrections:
1) Not-really-important nitpicks:

a) Turing Machines (TM) can solve all computable problems (so much so that the definition of a computable problems is kind of based on a TM)

b) Schrödinger's cat was originally about where are we supposed to draw the line between a quantum system and a classical one. In the original version, the cat (a supposedly classical being) is killed by a device that is randomly activated by the decay of an atom (that can actually experience superposition). Schrödinger was criticizing the scholastic interpretation of quantum mechanics by forcing their followers to admit that in this situation the cat had to behave quantumly and be in an absurd superposition of "alive" and "dead". Your description of the experiment makes it seem more a philosophical question than a scientific one.

c) Your description of the qubit was okay, but sadly the popular description of the inner workings of a quantum computer as "trying all the possibilities at once and choosing the right one" is just plain wrong. For one thing, it would give quantum computers the same power of a NTM (Nondeterministic TM), meaning that they could efficiently solve all problems in NP. That's not believed to be the case and has massive consequences on the known hierarchies of computational complexity.


2) More important points (IMHO):

a) "What counts as a practical amount of time"? This question is exactly why we work with complexity classes instead of amount of time. Quantum computer are NOT expected to solve all "the same problems that classical computers can solve, but way faster", only some of them. In fact, at the moment we know of a surprisingly low amount of useful (or even useless) problems where these speedups are significant.

b) Quantum Computational Supremacy (a very poorly chosen word) has nothing to do with demonstrating that quantum computers can efficiently solve useful problems, as you claim in the intro. I want to stress this point because showing supremacy is actually a fairly well-defined goal, contrary to what you said at the end of the video. It is reached whenever it can be experimentally shown that a given problem (even a completely useless one, but clear and concise) requires way less resources if quantum phenomena are exploited than on traditional, classical hardware. As is, the IBM response to Google's result doesn't lower a bit the complexity of solving their problem on a classical computer: instead it stems from an argument that in this case it is possible to trade cpu time for storage, if you have huge amounts (~100 Petabyte) of it. I however agree that it is quite a blow, and someone at Google's is probably banging his head against a wall for not factoring the possibility of exploiting such a huge amount of storage space into the calculations. Anyway, each qubit they add to the 53-qubit machine would translate in DOUBLE the space requirements for the IBM's proposal.

c) If the aim was just generating random numbers, as the video implies, generating a million of them in 200 seconds is not at all an impressive feat (even my phone could do it); certainly IBM wouldn't need hundreds of petabytes and 3 days on a supercomputer to replicate Google's result. And yes, for that classical computers are "just fine", as you say towards the end of the video.

d) And so we get to the crux of the matter, the problem solved by Google, called Random Circuit Sampling (RCS). What is it? It is quite technical, but a classical analogy with Galton boards (look them up) can be helpful. In a Galton board each time the board is flipped you end up with some random configuration of beads at the bottom, but you'll notice that it is not uniform; it has a generic "bell shape", and is called Normal distribution. In more formal language, Galton boards are computational devices that, while not having the full power of a Turing Machine, can still solve the problem of "extracting samples from the normal distribution". The device built by google is similar; you set it up in a specific way (the Circuit part in the name of the problem), feed a standard initial state at the input, run it and read a configuration at the output. As in the case with the Galton board, this configuration (sample) won't be uniform; it follows a specific distribution that depends on the settings of the device. Crucially, not only the specific shape of this distribution is extremely hard to compute on a classical device; it is even extremely hard to extract samples from it. But is this device as powerful as a full (quantum) Turing machine? Most probably not. Can it be used for something useful? We don't know, even if some proposals are out there (look up "Certified randomness generation"), but that was never the point.


3) Ending remarks
If you made this far, you're crazy (but I love you). These topics are fascinating and I glossed over some of the best parts (e.g. how they check that they have extracted good samples when there is no classical counterpart to compare the sample to, or why computer scientists are so convinced that a classical efficient algorithm for RCS cannot exist).
And can anyone have an idea of what the QC will do for video games?

Okay, so quantum computers are all neat and future-y and can do stupidly complex calculations and superposition is involved and also it's quantum mechanics so thinking about it makes my brain hurt, but nothing I've watched or read on them has answered the question that has bugged me about the whole proposition from the beginning.

Quantum computers simulate as many outcomes as possible at once using superposition of q-bits. Okay, with you so far. They then give you the right answer by collapsing that superposition down so that the observed q-bits are in the right configuration, but the q-bit configuration is random so... How? In every single video or article or whatever they gloss over this fact, but it kind of sounds like you have to KNOW the answer already in order to get the superposition to come out correctly, but if you know the answer then why ask the question? It seems less like science and more like a stage magician reaching into a swirling vortex of random paper slips so they can "magically" reveal the one with your name on it on the first try. What's the TRICK? How do you get the cat to do what you want and come out of the box in the correct state? The point of quantum conspiracy is the following: a company that owns a working quantum computer can easily crack everything that uses standard public-private key encription. Which is a lot of stuff.
So if the company actually reaches quantum supremacy - its the best interest of the company to keep it quiet and let the blame for hacks fall to the conventional cyber attacks. How many companies have already reached quantum supremacy while keeping quiet about it, hacking bank accounts and social networks to gather blackmail material for their political leverage?

Eh... The standard trap question in the undergrad exam about theorey of computation was if a computer can emulate a Turing Machine. And the correct answer is no because Turing Machines have infinite memory, that is their tape is infinitely long but any real world computer has finite memory.
That said, while theoreticists seem to be in love with Turing Machines at least for the purpose of torturing student brains I think they're so unhandy that they should probably be used to show other types of machines such as Register Machines are equivalent and from thereon those other machine modes should be used. IBM pointed out another problem with Google's announcement: their quantum computer relied on a classical computer doing computation beforehand in order to work.  The total amount of computation time was not measured in seconds but hours.

Depending on your favourite interpretation, of quantum mechanics, quantum computers can be mind-blowing. In the many-worlds model, we 'ask' our quantum computer a question and it 'splits' the labour, across a nearly infinite array of identical computers in parallel universes. Each tries a different solution to the same question and we then (somehow) filter out the correct answer. Wow!

1:57 "any combination of the two"
No, it can't have any combination. Only combinations that, when the superposition is represented as the vector z * |0〉 + w * |1〉 where z and w are complex numbers, obeys ||z^2|| + ||w^2|| = 1

You can't make up a combination where the weights are a kind of number with more dimensions than the complex plane (eg quaternions).

And you can't have 0 * |0〉 + 0 * |1〉 among other invalid vectors.

I always feel like the third state of Schrödinger's cat is described wrongly. The cat isn't both alive and dead, it's state is simply unknown.
Lets say you send your toddler to play in the backyard, while you do some work in your office at the other side of the house. Until you call them to come for dinner, you don't know whether they'll be clean or caked in mud. Would you say that your toddler is both clean and dirty at the same time? No, you'd say that you don't know. Same for the cat. And same for quantum bits. They're neither 0 nor 1 nor "any combination of those two" until you check, their state is simply unknown.

Quantum computers are only vastly better than classical computers on a specific set of computational tasks. Whether or not their superiority on those tasks can be leveraged to make quantum computers useful in general purpose computing applications doesn't have a clear answer at this time.

IMHO, Google chose a problem tailor made for the computer they built, and doesn't really demonstrate quantum supremacy. If their computer was flexible enough to be reprogrammed for a wide variety of different tasks, that would be a different story.

Great video on quantum supremacy. Near the latter half it was brought up that it can present problems to present day cryptography and gave some examples but kind of left it at that, which I think might unnecessarily worry some people

The great news for most people is that NIST, Google, and other bodies have recognized quantum computers as a threat to certain forms of present day encryption, so they're working diligently to ensure that there's post-quantum security in your browser before a sufficiently powerful enough quantum computer exists. This might seem paranoid, but for cryptographers and security professionals this is another day of the week - see it as taking an umbrella on a trip where you see in the forecast it's going to rain.

The bad news is if you're looking at blockchain such as Bitcoin, they also use the same quantum vulnerable ECDSA that's in your browser and also seem to be dismissing it, only wanting to do something maybe when ECDSA is broken. I hope people here can appreciate the problem this presents. There is one project, QRL (disclaimer: I'm part of the team), that uses post-quantum cryptography that's recognized by NIST and can operate at the same capacity as bitcoin.

To end things on a positive note, the potential for quantum computing to change how efficiently we can simulate real world systems accurately presents huge opportunities to advance medicine and materials science. Speculating, but I imagine when we can fully simulate multibody systems we're going to experience a speedup that's unparalleled to the advancements that we've seen before in science and technology.

Anyway, it's nice to see this topic discussed on a channel like SciShow, keep up the great work!

Turing machines cannot solve any mathematical problem. Uncomputable problems are a class of it’s own, and are caracterized by being impossible to solve (not just very hard). Turing machines also happen to be the most powerful model of computation that we know about, tied in first place with many others, so called “turing equivalents”, all of which can solve exactly the same set of problems as a Turing machine. Also, every model of computation that is not a Turing equivalent can only solve a strict sub set of the problems that a Turing equivalent can.

And now that we have mentioned Turing equivalents, I’d like to point out that modern computers are not in fact Turing machines. As the video shows, Turing machines are very limited in the instructions they use and the way they access memory. Generally CPUs can be modeled with what has been called register machines. These are Turing equivalent, so modern computers can indeed solve the same math problems that a Turing machine can, but this statement says nothing about the efficiency and ease of use of the machines. Turing machines are nice for mathematical proofs but they would make horrible real life computers.

Read up on the "P versus NP problem" to see why quantum computers are probably NOT a problem with respect to encryption and other applications that depend on difficult problems. The net of it is that there are problems whose "difficulty" grows exponentially so that if a problem of "size" 32 (32 bits, 32 nodes, 32 numbers, 32 characters, whatever) takes you 1 second to solve, then the same problem of size 64 would take you 58,494,242 years to solve with that same computer. Simply by doubling the "size" of the problem, you increase the time required to solve it by 4,294,967,296 times, no matter what kind of computer you're using. There appears to be a class of "difficult" problems whose difficulty to solve can easily be increased in such a way that even if you had the entire energy of the Sun at your disposal to work on the problem, it could be easily increased to require the entire computing energy of two Suns.
A Turing Machine is not capable of solving any mathematical problem. That was one of the fundamental points of Turing's thesis.

I actually sat in the audience of a symposium once where a Comp Sci professor was honest about what the challenges are with quantum computers and how the most advanced thing they had ever been able to do with one was calculate the square root of a number.

The overwhelming issue with quantum computers is that you are trying to use the position of a boson inside the nucleus of an atom as if it were a transistor. The problem is trying to set a quantum bit to a desired value and have it maintain that value. Bosons naturally interact with the quantum environment inside the atom and hence they change their orientation within the atom accordingly.

Now imagine trying to build a computer on something that had no way to maintain state. Because that is the problem you have with quantum computers. They come up with various ways to try and control the orientation of the boson inside an atom but they end up having algorithms on the order of Big O notation N squared to verify if the boson is in the correct orientation or not and then there is only some probability of less than 100% that the boson is in fact oriented properly.

Would it be awesome if you could use a quantum particle inside an atom to represent state just like a transistor does? Absolutely. But it is a futile effort due to two factors a) the above-mentioned problem of maintaining state within the nucleus of an atom and b) even if that wasn't problem enough you have to have the atoms interact somehow such that you can build logic gates, registers, floating point units, etc i.e. all the things that actually make a CPU work properly. And as far as I know atoms do not propagate the orientation of bosons within their nuclei from one atom to another, nor do they have the ability to change that state like a logic gate does in electrical engineering.

So to be honest, I'm not quite sure how they can get a quantum computer to do anything that would be considered productive. Other than true random number generation. In fact this may end up being the greatest contribution quantum computing provides is a means of generating true random numbers which is critical for things like encryption and information security. All you would have to do is simply observe the orientation of bosons within a set of atoms at a given point in time and assign bit-like values to the positions you observe. Computer scientists have always had a problem generating true random numbers but this would be trivial with a quantum RNG.

The explanation of Schrodinger's cat here is huge misrepresentation of the actual thought experiment and it's purpose. This most critical piece of the thought experiment was omitted: the "poison device" is triggered by a quantum event. The whole point was to directly tie quantum effects to classical effects. That is to say, if quantum mechanics really works this way, things on the larger scale must inescapably also work that way. Thus we are clearly missing something somewhere.


I think this is an important message, so it annoys me when Schrodinger's cat gets twisted into an explanation for how things work rather than what it was actually meant to represent.
